If that stem is dead you‚Äôll need to take cuttings of the living material above it if you want that to survive. The dead stem can‚Äôt come back to life and everything above it will continue to die off. Looks like there‚Äôs other living stems behind it tho, so you can pull this one out and replace it with the cuttings once they‚Äôve rooted. I‚Äôd recommend taking those cuttings now, and repotting the rest of the plant after it‚Äôs had about a week to acclimate to its new location. Good luck!

Basically, if you planted a Meyer lemon seed, you‚Äôre not going to get what you recognize as Meyer lemons from it. The consistency of Meyer lemons‚Äô flavor is because the whole of the crop is created via cloning and grafting, which produces genetically identical trees. The Meyer lemon is the result of generations of cross-breeding between different citrus varieties to attain a specific result and represents the pinnacle of genetic modification via selective breeding. Seeds from these lemons contain a variety of different genetic material and will not grow identically to the parent. You could end up with great lemons, crappy lemons, or no lemons at all. I still think you should keep growing though! It will be a fun experiment!
I think it depends on the cultivar and/or the producer. Is this a Meyer lemon?

If the soil has been kept moist for awhile, but the leaves are dry like this, then the roots may have rotted. I‚Äôd recommend de-potting to check the roots if that‚Äôs the case. If it was dry for a while and only recently watered, then just give it some more light (careful to avoid sunburn) and only water again when the soil has dried out. Good luck!

NTA - as someone with severe nausea, she shouldn‚Äôt be sitting in an exit row seat at all. I throw up on planes too, especially if I don‚Äôt have a window seat, and anytime I have to get a medical pass the gate crew will explicitly tell me that legally, I‚Äôm not allowed to sit in the exit row as any passenger sitting there must be willing and able to assist in an evacuation. Someone vomiting their face off is not physically able to perform evacuation procedures and thus would not be allowed to sit in the exit row as they are endangering the lives of other passengers.

I went to a Mary Kay party once about 10 years ago, I only knew a little about the MLM structure and I wanted to see what one of those parties was like. Well the makeup was horrible, no surprise. I was in college and just cluelessly tagged along with my roommate to the party, but despite everyone there being 18-24 years old, the presenter was a woman in her 40s who was ridiculously out of touch. I had short blue hair and she looked at me like I was the spawn of Satan and told me she didn‚Äôt have any shades that would ‚Äúcomplement that color‚Äù with a tone that could curdle milk. All the products were terrible quality and felt/looked/smelled like my mom‚Äôs old reject makeup from the 80s that she gave me to play with as a child. I don‚Äôt think anyone bought anything and my roommate and I left as quickly as we could after the whole sales spiel about ‚Äúlook at this pink Cadillac they give to top sellers, that could be you, sign up now!‚Äù Barf.

This. The blue dye really sticks to your hair while the pink/red tones wash right out. Lavender minus pink/red equals blue. Add some pink dye to your conditioner; if you‚Äôve added too much then your hair will be more pinkish than lavender until the next wash. Speaking of washing, I always think it‚Äôs good advice for colored hair to avoid washing it every day so as to not strip out the color. This is especially true for pastel colors - I‚Äôve found that I need to tone my hair about every other washing to maintain the perfect pastel shade so it‚Äôs definitely a bit more high-maintenance. Good luck!

Oh man that blue/green base is tough to get rid of. I managed to tone it out of my hair by using a rose-gold shade over it which acted as a color corrector. You can mix many vegetable-based semi-permanent dyes with your conditioner to maintain the color or to gently tone it to a different shade without using bleach. Good luck!

One of my favorite techniques to get root volume for my long thick hair is to braid it while it‚Äôs still damp from the shower and let it dry that way. Doing two French braids that start at the front of your head with a part down the middle is usually how I do it, and I‚Äôll add some product to help it stay nicely in the braids while it dries. My hair is naturally wavy but if I let it dry without trying to tame it, I end up with lots of frizz and tangles. This method works great with my hair‚Äôs natural wave and keeps it from immediately tangling. If you‚Äôve braided tightly to your scalp you should have loads of root volume when you remove the braids from your dry hair. Have fun!

YTA - you‚Äôve committed an embarrassing social faux pas with everyone in the equation honestly.
Your daughter, a teenager, is going to feel hurt and mortified by the ordeal of having an out-of-touch parent jealously taking back a gift they received, and your lesson about learning the value of money is so far off base it‚Äôs not even funny. What do you think does a better job of educating a child on financial inequality than another person having the means to casually give them a gift they could never afford to buy themselves? Do you consider your child so stupid, and you so careless, that you couldn‚Äôt bother to address this concern with an educational conversation? It‚Äôs pretty rude and telling that you don‚Äôt think you did a good enough job raising your own offspring for them to, as a teenager, not somehow destroy a scarf. And yeah, that‚Äôs definitely the message your child is hearing. It‚Äôs hugely tacky and in very poor taste to steal a gift from someone to return it because you don‚Äôt think they deserve it.
You‚Äôve also offended your son and his girlfriend by showing that you don‚Äôt value their intelligence enough to accept a gift the girlfriend chose to give - implying she were too stupid to realize your poorly-raised child would obviously destroy the gift and doesn‚Äôt even deserve any expensive item anyways. That‚Äôs the message you‚Äôre sending, even if it‚Äôs not what you intend; that‚Äôs how it reads to the other people involved. 
If I was your teenage child, I‚Äôd be hurt, embarrassed, and frankly would consider this incident a telling moment as to how you feel about me and would not be feeling particularly inclined to trust you or share things with you anymore.

You‚Äôre welcome! Fun fact: central Florida is known as ‚Äúlightning alley‚Äù due to the frequency of thunderstorms. This is caused by the tropical climate and peninsula shape - the humid swamp air warms up as the sun rises and starts to condense into clouds which are blown inward by the cooler sea breezes, colliding in the center of the state and coming down in the form of thunderstorms. It‚Äôs an incredibly humid place and Disney World is built in the center of soggy swampland that Walt Disney bought up for cheap back in the 1960s. If you‚Äôll have smart phone service while you‚Äôre visiting, it‚Äôs a good idea to download a weather app that features a radar map setting so you can monitor the storms as they approach/condense and plan accordingly!

As a former Orlando resident, be prepared for thunderstorms around 2pm every day. Honestly even if it doesn‚Äôt rain each day you‚Äôll be glad to have packed your suitcase in anticipation of it. Lots of people will bail out of the parks when the sky opens up but if you can camp out in a restaurant during that time you can wait out the storm and then take advantage of shorter lines afterward. Have fun!

When I worked retail in the US, if we suspected a person of shoplifting, nothing could be done unless you saw the person put something in their bag or pocket, never took your eyes off of them after seeing this, alerted a manager if you weren‚Äôt one (without breaking eye contact with the suspected shoplifter), and watched them leaving the store. At this point the manager would have to ask the customer to stay while mall security was called but could in no way detain them - the person could just refuse and leave. If any of these steps were skipped, the customer could sue the store and any employees involved could be fired.

If you live in the US, you likely have a good basis for complaint or even legal action.

The twist braids are my favorite! I hope you have fun and it works out well for you!

I usually do either two French braids or two twist braids, with my hair parted down the center and a braid on each side. The twist braids will make spiral curls and the French braid will make waves so I‚Äôd say try them both and see which you like best! I used to use this awesome ‚Äúbraid cream‚Äù which I think has been discontinued and I can‚Äôt find it anywhere now, but if you have any product to put in it will help keep the braids from getting too frizzy while you sleep. Have fun!

My hair strategy when I lived in Florida was to try to braid or put my hair up to minimize the water exposure and keep it from getting tangled if it did get wet. I have very long thick hair so if I let it flow loose I‚Äôd have to just accept the tangled mess it would become and try to let it dry enough to gather into a messy sort of updo. I love the feeling of washing my hair after a day at the beach and getting all that salt or chlorine out! In my experience the chlorine was more damaging than the salt water, I‚Äôve even seen salt-water hair sprays designed to add that beachy texture without spending a day in Florida. Definitely only wash it once per day though, it would be more damaging to wash it every time it got wet than to let some salt or chlorine water dry in your hair and then get wet again later. Just finish out your nights with a good wash and your curl care routine!

As far as second-day hair, it is all gonna depend on how the humidity affects you. I washed my hair once or twice a week tops when I lived there because when it was freshly washed it was a frizzy disaster. My hair takes forever to dry and with the heat and humidity it would just frizz out like crazy until it got enough oil from my scalp (or me adding product) to smooth out. Plenty of my friends had the opposite problem. It‚Äôs all about the texture! But for second day hair in general I think braids are a good way to go with plenty of different options.

Have fun in Florida and don‚Äôt forget your sunscreen!
Have you tried braiding your hair overnight? It will help form more waves too.
